verses.text: The oracle against Babylon that Isaiah, the son of Amoz, saw:
verses.comment: The term 'oracle' refers to a prophetic burden or message of judgment. Isaiah receives a vision specifically directed against Babylon, one of Israel's greatest future enemies (see Jeremiah 50-51).

verses.text: Raise a banner on a bare hill, call out to them with a loud voice; wave your hand, so they may enter the gates of the nobles.
verses.comment: A rallying signal for assembling armies, God directs the nations to prepare for Babylon’s judgment. The gates of the nobles refers to the city of Babylon’s proud rulers.

verses.text: I myself have commanded my consecrated ones; I have summoned my warriors, those who rejoice in my triumph, to execute my wrath.
verses.comment: The 'consecrated ones' are not Israelites, but the nations (like the Medes) set apart by God for His purpose (see v. 17). God’s sovereignty and use of earthly powers as instruments aligns with later prophecies of deliverance.

verses.text: A sound! A tumult on the mountains, like that of a great multitude! The noise of kingdoms, nations gathering together! The LORD of hosts is mustering an army for battle.
verses.comment: Imagery describing the clash of nations under divine command. The title 'LORD of hosts' emphasizes God’s supreme authority over every army—spiritual and earthly.

verses.text: They come from a far country, from the ends of the heavens— the LORD and the weapons of his indignation— to destroy the whole land.
verses.comment: God uses far-off nations as tools of His judgment. This prophecy points toward historic invasions but also reveals God’s initiative in salvation history.

verses.text: Wail, for the day of the LORD is near; it will come like destruction from the Almighty.
verses.comment: The 'day of the LORD' is a recurring prophetic theme—judgment on evil but hope for the faithful. See parallels in Zephaniah and Joel.

verses.text: Therefore all hands will hang limp, every human heart will melt,
verses.comment: Common biblical imagery for overwhelming fear. Humans are powerless before God’s judgment.

verses.text: They will be terrified—anguish and pain will seize them; they will writhe like a woman in labor. They will look at one another in shock, their faces aflame.
verses.comment: 'Like a woman in labor' is a frequent Old Testament image for intense distress (see Jeremiah 6:24). The ordeal anticipates coming calamity and, spiritually, the pain of awaiting final redemption.

verses.text: Look! The day of the LORD is coming, cruel, with fury and burning anger, to make the earth a desolation and destroy its sinners from it.
verses.comment: Sinners are set in opposition to God’s holiness. The 'day of the LORD' is both a historical and eschatological idea, prefiguring God’s final judgment.

verses.text: For the stars of the heavens and their constellations will not give their light; the sun will be dark when it rises, and the moon will not shed its light.
verses.comment: Cosmic disturbances symbolize world-changing events (see Joel 2:10, Rev. 6:12). Jesus echoes these signs in His prophecy of the end times, showing continuity in prophetic revelation.

verses.text: I will punish the world for its evil, and the wicked for their iniquity; I will bring an end to the arrogance of the proud, and lay low the insolence of the ruthless.
verses.comment: Justice is universal—God's judgment is not only against Babylon but also all human pride and wickedness. This foreshadows the future day when Christ will return as Judge (Rev. 20:12).

verses.text: I will make people scarcer than fine gold, mankind rarer than the gold of Ophir.
verses.comment: Ophir was famous for its pure gold. The coming judgment will be so severe that survivors will be rare (see Matthew 24:22 for eschatological parallels).

verses.text: Therefore I will make the heavens tremble, and the earth will shake from its place at the wrath of the LORD of armies in the day of his fierce anger.
verses.comment: A strong image: God’s judgment alters the very fabric of creation. Hebrews 12:26-27 makes use of this theme, connecting it to the unshakable kingdom brought by Christ.

verses.text: Like hunted gazelles, like sheep with no one to gather them, everyone will return to his own people, and each will flee to his own land.
verses.comment: The flight and scattering evoke images later applied to Israel’s exile and return. Jesus refers to sheep without a shepherd, pointing to the need for true spiritual leadership and unity.

verses.text: Whoever is found will be pierced through, and whoever is caught will fall by the sword.
verses.comment: A stark description of the coming destruction—indiscriminate and complete. This reflects the seriousness of God’s justice.

verses.text: Their infants will be dashed to pieces before their eyes; their houses will be plundered, and their wives violated.
verses.comment: The horror described is not a call to violence but a prophecy of what occurs when God’s protection is withdrawn. It highlights the gravity of sin and divine justice.

verses.text: Look! I am stirring up the Medes against them, who have no regard for silver and take no pleasure in gold.
verses.comment: This specific reference (fulfilled in Daniel 5 with the fall of Babylon) demonstrates God’s absolute control over history. The Medes didn’t attack for plunder but were instruments of divine will.

verses.text: Their bows will strike down the young men; they will have no mercy on the fruit of the womb; their eyes will not pity children.
verses.comment: The Medes’ mercilessness fulfills the prophecy. Such severe language shows how sin leads to devastating consequences and the need for grace and protection from the Good Shepherd.

verses.text: And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the splendor and pride of the Chaldeans, will be like Sodom and Gomorrah when God overthrew them.
verses.comment: Babylon, symbolizing human pride, is directly compared to Sodom and Gomorrah—classic images of total destruction (see Rev. 18 for Babylon as a symbol of evil, opposed to God’s city). A warning against pride and a call to humility.

verses.text: It will never be inhabited or lived in from generation to generation; Arabs will not pitch their tents there, shepherds will not make their flocks lie down there.
verses.comment: Total desolation—God’s judgment is final. Historically, Babylon was never rebuilt as a great city. This has spiritual significance as a symbol of God’s unshakeable kingdom replacing earthly powers.

verses.text: But wild animals will lie there, and their houses will be full of owls; ostriches will dwell there, and wild goats will leap about.
verses.comment: Desolation leads to a reversal—once a great city, now home to unclean animals. The picture points to the futility of prideful rebellion against God.

verses.text: Hyenas will howl in its strongholds, jackals in the luxurious palaces; her time is coming soon, her days will not be prolonged.
verses.comment: Despite Babylon’s former glory, its judgment is certain and swift. The finality here speaks of God’s faithfulness to His promises—He preserves His remnant through tribulation and establishes a permanent kingdom.
